Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Gender Bias and Stereotype Threat in Surgical Training

Trial_Design.evidence: permuted-block design stratified by site, training level, and gender

Participants.evidence: Participants were 96 general surgery residents with academic career interests, recruited between August 1 and August 15, 2018.

Intervention.evidence: randomised 1:1 using permuted-block design stratified by site, training level, and gender to receive either a stereotype threat trigger or protection.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the association between pro-male gender bias and career engagement, and the effect of stereotype threat on skill performance among surgical trainees.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Fundamentals of Laparoscopic Surgery (FLS) score, measured immediately post-intervention.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: randomised 1:1 using permuted-block design stratified by site, training level, and gender

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was maintained for outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants were 96 general surgery residents with academic career interests, recruited between August 1 and August 15, 2018.
